attributes.title: Interpersonal Emotion Regulation and its Relation to Anxiety

q1.value: Interpersonal Emotion Regulation and its Relation to Anxiety

q2.value: William Michael Vanderlind, Jonas Everaert, Camila Cabarello, Dylan Gee

q3.value: Many studies show that difficulties with emotion regulation are related to anxiety. For instance, individuals with a diagnosis of anxiety are more likely to use putatively maladaptive emotion regulation strategies (i.e., strategies that ineffectively decrease negative affect or inadvertently increase negative affect), such as rumination, and are less likely to use adaptive strategies, such as reappraisal (Aldao, Nolen-Hoeksema, & Schweizer, 2010). Rumination refers to a cyclical style of thought wherein individuals think about the causes and consequences of negative affect and clinical symptoms such as anxiety and depression (Nolen-Hoeksema, Wisco, & Lyubomirski, 2008), and reappraisal refers to an emotion regulation strategy in which people change their appraisal of situation to modulate subsequent emotional responding–for example, they may substitute a negative interpretation of an ambiguous event for a neutral or positive interpretation (Gross & John, 2003). Of note, most studies on rumination and reappraisal in anxiety focus on intrapersonal use of the strategy, but emotions do not occur in isolation. Rather, they are often experienced within social contexts, and, among the general population, it is not uncommon for other people to help someone regulate their emotions during periods of negative affect. The involvement of another person in the regulation of affect is known as interpersonal emotion regulation. Despite the abundance of research on anxiety and intrapersonal emotion regulation, there is a paucity of research on interpersonal rumination and reappraisal as they relate to anxiety. The current study therefore seeks to examine the nature of interpersonal emotion regulation–specifically rumination and reappraisal–as it relates to individual differences in anxiety. The first two primary questions are as follows: 1) does anxiety relate to the extent to which other people assist with interpersonal rumination and reappraisal?; 2) is anxiety associated with the effectiveness of interpersonal emotion regulation, as indexed by participants’ perception of regulatory effectiveness? In addition to the link between interpersonal emotion regulation and anxiety, this study aims to examine whether the relation between anxiety and the intrapersonal use of rumination and reappraisal varies between social and non-social contexts.

q4.value: Given the dearth of research on interpersonal rumination and reappraisal as they relate to anxiety, most of the above-mentioned research questions are exploratory in nature. The existing literature does not point to strong a priori hypotheses with respect to the first research question. However, based on research showing that anxiety is related to interpersonal problems (e.g., hostile interactions, avoidance of social situations), it is plausible that greater levels of anxiety are associated with fewer occasions to regulate emotions within interpersonal relations and, thus, are linked to less frequent interpersonal rumination and reappraisal. In regard to the second research question, prior research has linked anxiety to relative reductions in the effectiveness of intrapersonal emotion regulation in general. Therefore, it is possible that interpersonal effectiveness, too, will be negatively associated with individual differences in anxiety. More specifically, individuals who report relatively greater levels of anxiety are hypothesized to report less perceived effectiveness of reappraisal and rumination compared to individuals who endorse relatively less anxiety. Finally, we do not have strong a priori hypotheses in regard to the third research question. That said, anxiety is often characterized by interpersonal distress. Given that anxiety is associated with more use of rumination and less use of reappraisal in general, it is reasonable to expect that associations between anxiety and intrapersonal strategy use will become stronger (i.e., even more rumination and less reappraisal) within social situations – a context often marked by increased stress for those with an anxiety disorder.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The present investigation involves an ecological momentary assessment (EMA) paradigm. Participants first attend a laboratory-based experiment session and subsequently complete questionnaires that measure various aspects of state emotion, use of emotion regulation strategies, and environmental context four times per day for 14 days.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: The primary research questions described above are part of a larger ongoing study. The first two authors (Vanderlind and Everaert) were not involved in the original creation of the study or the acquisition of these data. Similarly, these authors have not yet accessed the data beyond calculating the number of participants with complete data to address the primary research questions listed here. None of the included authors have begun to analyze the data to address the questions listed here. To this extent, we pre-registered our primary research questions prior to analysis.

question.value:
Participants were recruited from the New Haven area through flyers, word-of-mouth referrals, and online study advertisements. Participants were screened to meet the following criteria: (a) 18 to 30 years old; (b) eligible for an MRI scan (included for a separate research question); (c) right-handed (also included for a separate research question); (d) no cognitive impairment (IQ <80); (e) no history of head injury or concussion; (f) no history of chronic medical illness or neurological disorder. 
Participants first completed a laboratory-based session, in which they completed a broad battery of questionnaires (implemented via REDCap), cognitive testing using the Wechsler Abbreviated Scale of Intelligence-Second Edition (WASI-II; Wechsler, 2011), and a clinical interview (Anxiety Disorders Interview Schedule for DSM-5; Brown & Barlow, 2014). 
Prior to the initiation of the EMA paradigm, participants returned to the lab to complete an onboarding procedure for the EMA component of the study. The onboarding process entailed education on the nature of the survey questions and the establishment of a customized schedule for EMA survey distribution. Four surveys were delivered via REDCap, a HIPAA-compliant platform for data collection, across the morning, midday, afternoon, and evening times, with at least two hours in between each survey. Participants were instructed to respond as soon as possible after receiving each survey, and to respond at least within one hour. Participants received four surveys via text messaging each day for 14 days, yielding a maximum total of 56 time points per individual. After completing the orientation, participants were enrolled in the EMA paradigm, which generally began the day after the onboarding session unless they had an upcoming vacation that would disrupt their “usual” daily schedules. In these instances, the EMA procedure began soon upon their return.
The EMA paradigm involved the collection of real-time data on emotional experiences and emotion regulation. As mentioned, the paradigm involved four surveys per day for 14 days, with a total of 56 possible time points per participant. The surveys asked participants about their environmental context (e.g., social interaction, location), self-reported affect (i.e., sadness, fear, anger, happiness), and regulatory strategy use at each time point. During the last survey of the day, participants additionally reported on the worst moment of their day. This retrospective recall at the end of the day included questions on self-reported affect prior to using any regulatory strategies when they were feeling their worst, which regulatory strategies they used at the time, perceived efficacy of regulatory strategy selected (e.g., “Overall, how much did changing the way you were thinking about the way you were feeling help you to manage [your feelings]?”), and their self-reported affect after using these regulatory strategies.

Variable operationalization: For the primary aims of the current study, we will operationalize anxiety using two dimensional measures: the STAI and the BAI. The STAI will be used to index trait anxiety, and the BAI will be used as a measure of anxiety symptoms. Interpersonal emotion regulation will be measured using variables from the fourth and final EMA survey of each day (i.e., ratings related to participants’ “worst moment” of the day). Interpersonal emotion regulation will be indexed dimensionally using slider scale responses on the extent to which (0 to 100) someone else was involved in helping participants implement reappraisal and rumination. Intrapersonal emotion regulation will be measured using binary response selections as to whether reappraisal and rumination were used (yes, no) but only during instances in which other people were not involved in strategy implementation. Social context will also be measured categorically; situations in which participants were alone and not engaged in digital communications will be coded as a non-social context, and situations in which participants were in an environment with someone else will be coded as a social context. Emotion regulation effectiveness will be indexed by participants’ ratings of perceived effectiveness of reappraisal and rumination.

Measured variables: Anxiety was measured in multiple ways that were collected prior to the initiation of the EMA procedures. The Anxiety Disorders Interview Schedule for DSM-5 (Brown & Barlow, 2014) was used to assess for current and past anxiety disorder diagnoses. Self-report measures of anxiety were also collected. These included the Spielberger State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI; Spielberger, Gorsuch, Lushene, Vagg, & Jacobs, 1983), the Penn State Worry Questionnaire (PSWQ; Meyer, Miller, Metzger, & Borkovec, 1990), the Beck Anxiety Inventory (BAI; Beck, Epstein, Brown, & Steer, 1988), and the Screening for Child Anxiety and Related Emotional Disorders (SCARED; Birmaher, Brent, Chiappetta, Bridge, Monga, & Baugher, 1999). Self-reported depressive symptoms (i.e., Beck Depression Inventory-II; Beck, Steer, & Brown, 1996) and trauma (i.e., Trauma Symptom Checklist-40; Elliot & Briere, 1992) were also collected. Finally, measures of trait emotion regulation strategy use, including the Emotion Regulation Questionnaire (ERQ; Gross & John, 2003) and Difficulties in Emotion Regulation Scale (DERS; Gratz & Roemer, 2004), were collected prior to the EMA procedure.
The EMA surveys asked participants about their self-reported affect (i.e., sadness, fear, anger, happiness) and regulatory strategy use at each time point. Participants rated their affect using a sliding scale from 0 (not at all) to 100 (very much). Strategy use was assessed by having participants select all strategies that were used within the specified time frame (see data collection procedures). Emotion regulation strategies that were assessed within the current study included rumination, acceptance, suppression, distraction, and reappraisal. Engagement in each strategy was measured using a single item, and responses were binary (yes, no). Participants also rated the extent to which they perceived the strategy as effective using a sliding scale from 0 (not at all) to 100 (very much). In addition, information regarding the environmental context was collected. This included whether the person was alone or with others and, if the latter, whom the person was with (e.g., parent, friend, etc.). Engagement with another person via digital conversation (e.g., phone, text message, etc.) was also assessed. Finally, the extent to which another person was involved in using a given regulatory strategy was measured using a sliding scale from 0 (not at all) to 100 (very much). Whereas the first three surveys of each day were focused on the hour immediately preceding the survey, the fourth and final survey of each day asked participants to identify and focus on the period of the day during which they felt the worst. As part of the final EMA survey, participants rated their emotional states at the peak of their “worst moment”, indicated which emotion regulation strategies were used, rated the extent to which other people helped implement a given strategy, and rated emotion states again after emotion regulation. Similar to the first three surveys of each day, participants provided information on the context of their “worst moment” (i.e., if they were alone or around others, if they were engaged in a face-to-face or digital conversation, etc.).

Aim 1: Hierarchical linear regression will be used to examine the relation between anxiety and the extent of interpersonal emotion regulation strategy use across the entire EMA period. Predictor variables in the model will include anxiety (STAI and BAI, run in separate models), emotion regulation strategy (reappraisal and rumination), and the interaction between anxiety and strategy. The degree of help during strategy use will be entered as the criterion variable.
Aim 2: Linear regression will also be used to address whether anxiety relates to the effectiveness of interpersonal reappraisal and rumination.  Anxiety will again be entered as a predictor variable, as will the extent of interpersonal emotion regulation (reappraisal and rumination will be tested in separate models). The criterion variable will be self-reported perceived effectiveness of emotion regulation strategy implementation.
Aim 3: Similar to Aims 1 and 2, linear regression will be used to test whether the relation between anxiety and intrapersonal emotion regulation strategy use differs across context (social, non-social). Anxiety, context (social, non-social), and their interaction will be entered as predictor variables, and the frequency of reappraisal and rumination across the entire EMA period will be entered as criterion variables in separate models.

q24.value: Exploratory analyses: In addition to examining reappraisal and rumination, the aforementioned analyses will also be conducted utilizing the other emotion regulation strategies (acceptance, suppression, distraction) that were assessed as part of the EMA paradigm. These results will be presented in a supplement of the paper. Moreover, individual differences in depressive symptoms (i.e., BDI-II scores) will be considered in the analyses to examine the extent to which observed findings are specific to anxiety. In addition to examining a composite measure of negative affect, we will run the above-mentioned analyses specifically examining self-reported anxiety given the nature of the clinical presentation of interest as well as with positive emotion as an outcome variable to, again, probe the specificity with which observed findings relate to negative versus positive affect.

attributes.title: Teaching evaluation bias: the effect of field of study

q1.value: Gender Bias in Teaching Evaluations: The effect of field of study

q3.value:
The recent decades have seen a surge of evidence in higher education settings pointing to a gender bias in teaching evaluations (Langbein, 1994; MacNell, Driscoll, & Hunt, 2015; Ottoboni, Boring, & Stark, 2016; Pounder, 2007; Wagner, Rieger, & Voorvelt, 2016; Young, Rush, &; Shaw, 2009; Boring 2017; Mengel, Sauermann & Zolitz 2018). This finding constitutes a major problem because there is a tradition to associate teaching evaluations with educational outcomes and to decide on the careers of academics based on teaching evaluations (Wild & Berger, 2016). To the extent that teaching evaluations assess academics in a biased way, based on their gender rather than specific behaviours, decisions that are key to academic careers may be unfair. For example, the under-representation of women in senior academic roles, especially in male-dominated disciplines, may be due to unfair decisions early in the careers of female academics (Dick & Nadin, 2006; Moss-Racusin, Dovidio, Brescoll, Graham, & Handelsman, 2012; Newsome, 2008; Sheltzer & Smith, 2014; Way, Larremore, & Clauset, 2016).

The research question of this study is to specifically assess if gender bias in teaching evaluations depends on the field of study: is there gender bias in male and female stereotypical disciplines?

q4.value:
H1: A female (as compared to a male) academic will be evaluated less positively for delivering the same lecture content in the male-stereotypical disciplines but not in the female-stereotypical discipline (in terms of their overall evaluation, the evaluation of the taught content, and the willingness to enrol in their class).  

H2: Gender bias (as per H1) will be mediated by the perceptions of the academic's warmth and/or competence.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: The participants will not know that there different treatments of the study. Since the experiment is online there is no interaction between the researcher and the participants.

question.value: 2x2 between subject experiment conducted online in Prolific.ac platform. See the attachment for the full experimental tool.

q9.value: Randomized allocation of each respondent to 2x2 condition: simple randomization

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: Two studies have been already conducted and written up using an astronomy as a field of study, that have informed the design of this study on teaching evaluation bias.

question.value:
We will use participant pool from Prolific.ac.uk
We will pre-screen participants to have student status and be between 18-30 of age. 
The participants are already registered in the website and will be self-selecting themselves to participate in our study. The participation will take around 10 minutes and participants will receive £0.75 fixed rate  + bonus payments depending on their manipulation check answers.  All treatments will run simultaneously by randomly allocating each participant to a single treatment. This will be automatically done by Qualtrics software.

q14.value:
The study will consist of a 2 (gender: male vs. female) x 2 (financial engineering vs. social psychology) between-subjects design. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the four conditions. The number of participants required for the study is determined based on a-priori power analysis with anticipated small effect sizes (i.e., Cohen’s f  = .15) which would require a sample size of 460 to be powered at 90%. All power calculations were conducted using G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007). 

We will collect +30 observations for possible missing data or manipulation check failures.

Faul, F., Erdfelder, E., Lang, A. G., Lang; Buchner, A. (2007). G* Power 3: A flexible statistical power analysis program for the social, behavioral, and biomedical sciences. Behavior Research Methods, 39(2), 175-191.

q15.value: Set by prolific.com when specified sample size is reached.

question.value:
Field of study as a binary treatment variable: stereotypically-male discipline (financial engineering) versus stereotypically-female discipline (social psychology). These were pretested in a study to elicit students' stereotypes about disciplines in an incentivized way. 
Gender as a binary treatment variable: male or female (name and silhouette of head and shoulders) at the top left of the lecture.

The Scale: Disagree Strongly, Disagree Moderately, Disagree Slightly, Neither Agree nor Disagree, Agree Slightly, Agree Moderately, Agree Strongly.

Mediators
The candidate will reach the Full Professor position during their academic career [comp_obj_3]
The candidate was professional. [comp_subj_1]
The candidate was knowledgeable.[comp_subj_2]
The candidate mastered the content of the lecture. [comp_subj_3]
The candidate was a warm person.  [warm_subj_1]
The candidate was an approachable person.  [warm_subj_2]
The candidate was enthusiastic.  [warm_subj_3]

DV: 
If I could, I would enrol in the class taught by this candidate [enr_subj_1]
If the class taught by this candidate was oversubscribed, I would join the waiting list hoping to take it eventually [enr_subj_2]
I would recommend the class taught by this candidate to other students who might be interested in finance [overall_subj_1]
I think that the candidate should be hired [overall_subj_2]
The lecture material was intellectually stimulating. [content_subj_1]
The lecture material was of high quality. [content_subj_2]
I think the lecturer is highly skilled. [overall_subj_3]

Manipulation checks: 
Was the candidate? [female_check]
Choose from: Male, Female, Unknown
 
What field was the lecture on: 
Sociology, finance, history
 
Which of the following was TRUE about the candidate?
The candidate allowed questions at any point in the lecture
The candidate discouraged questions during the lecture

Which of the following was TRUE about the candidate?
The candidate seemed condescending at some points during the lecture
The candidate did not seem condescending at any point during the lecture

Which of the following was TRUE about the candidate?
After the lecture, the candidate showed availability to discuss lecture content in person.
After the lecture, the candidate did not show availability to discuss lecture content in person

Control questions
Subject's Gender (Male/Female)
Subject's Age
Subject's years of speaking English
Subject's highest education level
Subject's Country of Birth
Subject's subject matter familiarity (student of finance/social psych or related vs. not)
Ease/difficulty of imagining the lecture/realism of the lecture

We will run the following command to generate objective and subjective measures for each key variable.
alpha warm_subj_1 warm_subj_2 warm_subj_3, generate(WARMTH_SUBJ)
alpha comp_subj_1 comp_subj_2 comp_subj_3, generate(COMPETENCE_SUBJ)
alpha content_subj_1 content_subj_2 , generate(CONTENT_SUBJ)
alpha enr_subj_1 enr_subj_2, generate(ENROLLMENT_SUBJ)
alpha overall_subj_1 overall_subj_2 overall_subj_3, generate(OVERALL_SUBJ)

We will use items that have alpha of at least 0.60, and will run CFA analyses to make sure our variables measures are distinct.

STATA will be used. Linear regressions, simple slopes analyses and planned contrasts will be used to test our research hypotheses. Path analysis and multiple mediator analysis will be used to quantify the direct and indirect effects of gender.
Below, we explain what regression analyses will be conducted and how our research hypotheses will be tested within these analyses:
1.	Regressions of the overall evaluation of the academic (OVERALL_OBJ), the evaluation of the taught content (CONTENT_OBJ), and the willingness to enrol (ENROLLMENT_OBJ):

reg ENROLLMENT_SUBJ  i.MALE##i.FinanceDISCIPLINE  Controls
reg CONTENT_SUBJ   i.MALE##i.FinanceDISCIPLINE Controls
reg OVERALL_SUBJ  i.MALE##i.FinanceDISCIPLINE Controls


Check for Mediation
reg ENROLLMENT/CONTENT/OVERALL WARMTH_SUBJ   COMPETENCE_SUBJ 
 i.MALE##i.FinanceDISCIPLINE Controls

q21.value: We will report significance with 10%, 5% and 1% levels, where 10% is suggestive evidence, 5% is significant, 1% is strongly significant

q22.value: All individuals who have failed 50% or more of manipulation check questions will be excluded. This aims to avoid participants skimming through the survey without paying attention to claim the fixed payments for little effort. In addition, we may look specifically into the time spent on reading the lecture content and eliminate those who fulfil that portion of the questionnaire too quickly. In the case of repeat IP addresses in the data, we will conduct analysis eliminating such data points.

q23.value: Observations with missing data in terms of dependent variables will be dropped.

registration_responses.q1: Gender Bias in Teaching Evaluations: The effect of field of study
registration_responses.q3:
The recent decades have seen a surge of evidence in higher education settings pointing to a gender bias in teaching evaluations (Langbein, 1994; MacNell, Driscoll, & Hunt, 2015; Ottoboni, Boring, & Stark, 2016; Pounder, 2007; Wagner, Rieger, & Voorvelt, 2016; Young, Rush, &; Shaw, 2009; Boring 2017; Mengel, Sauermann & Zolitz 2018). This finding constitutes a major problem because there is a tradition to associate teaching evaluations with educational outcomes and to decide on the careers of academics based on teaching evaluations (Wild & Berger, 2016). To the extent that teaching evaluations assess academics in a biased way, based on their gender rather than specific behaviours, decisions that are key to academic careers may be unfair. For example, the under-representation of women in senior academic roles, especially in male-dominated disciplines, may be due to unfair decisions early in the careers of female academics (Dick & Nadin, 2006; Moss-Racusin, Dovidio, Brescoll, Graham, & Handelsman, 2012; Newsome, 2008; Sheltzer & Smith, 2014; Way, Larremore, & Clauset, 2016).

The research question of this study is to specifically assess if gender bias in teaching evaluations depends on the field of study: is there gender bias in male and female stereotypical disciplines?
registration_responses.q4:
H1: A female (as compared to a male) academic will be evaluated less positively for delivering the same lecture content in the male-stereotypical disciplines but not in the female-stereotypical discipline (in terms of their overall evaluation, the evaluation of the taught content, and the willingness to enrol in their class).  

H2: Gender bias (as per H1) will be mediated by the perceptions of the academic's warmth and/or competence.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q7: The participants will not know that there different treatments of the study. Since the experiment is online there is no interaction between the researcher and the participants.
registration_responses.q9: Randomized allocation of each respondent to 2x2 condition: simple randomization
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q11: Two studies have been already conducted and written up using an astronomy as a field of study, that have informed the design of this study on teaching evaluation bias.
registration_responses.q14:
The study will consist of a 2 (gender: male vs. female) x 2 (financial engineering vs. social psychology) between-subjects design. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the four conditions. The number of participants required for the study is determined based on a-priori power analysis with anticipated small effect sizes (i.e., Cohen’s f  = .15) which would require a sample size of 460 to be powered at 90%. All power calculations were conducted using G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007). 

We will collect +30 observations for possible missing data or manipulation check failures.

Faul, F., Erdfelder, E., Lang, A. G., Lang; Buchner, A. (2007). G* Power 3: A flexible statistical power analysis program for the social, behavioral, and biomedical sciences. Behavior Research Methods, 39(2), 175-191.
registration_responses.q15: Set by prolific.com when specified sample size is reached.

registration_responses.q22: All individuals who have failed 50% or more of manipulation check questions will be excluded. This aims to avoid participants skimming through the survey without paying attention to claim the fixed payments for little effort. In addition, we may look specifically into the time spent on reading the lecture content and eliminate those who fulfil that portion of the questionnaire too quickly. In the case of repeat IP addresses in the data, we will conduct analysis eliminating such data points.
registration_responses.q23: Observations with missing data in terms of dependent variables will be dropped.
registration_responses.q8.question: 2x2 between subject experiment conducted online in Prolific.ac platform. See the attachment for the full experimental tool.
registration_responses.q12.question:
We will use participant pool from Prolific.ac.uk
We will pre-screen participants to have student status and be between 18-30 of age. 
The participants are already registered in the website and will be self-selecting themselves to participate in our study. The participation will take around 10 minutes and participants will receive £0.75 fixed rate  + bonus payments depending on their manipulation check answers.  All treatments will run simultaneously by randomly allocating each participant to a single treatment. This will be automatically done by Qualtrics software.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Field of study as a binary treatment variable: stereotypically-male discipline (financial engineering) versus stereotypically-female discipline (social psychology). These were pretested in a study to elicit students' stereotypes about disciplines in an incentivized way. 
Gender as a binary treatment variable: male or female (name and silhouette of head and shoulders) at the top left of the lecture.
registration_responses.q17.question:
The Scale: Disagree Strongly, Disagree Moderately, Disagree Slightly, Neither Agree nor Disagree, Agree Slightly, Agree Moderately, Agree Strongly.

Mediators
The candidate will reach the Full Professor position during their academic career [comp_obj_3]
The candidate was professional. [comp_subj_1]
The candidate was knowledgeable.[comp_subj_2]
The candidate mastered the content of the lecture. [comp_subj_3]
The candidate was a warm person.  [warm_subj_1]
The candidate was an approachable person.  [warm_subj_2]
The candidate was enthusiastic.  [warm_subj_3]

DV: 
If I could, I would enrol in the class taught by this candidate [enr_subj_1]
If the class taught by this candidate was oversubscribed, I would join the waiting list hoping to take it eventually [enr_subj_2]
I would recommend the class taught by this candidate to other students who might be interested in finance [overall_subj_1]
I think that the candidate should be hired [overall_subj_2]
The lecture material was intellectually stimulating. [content_subj_1]
The lecture material was of high quality. [content_subj_2]
I think the lecturer is highly skilled. [overall_subj_3]

Manipulation checks: 
Was the candidate? [female_check]
Choose from: Male, Female, Unknown
 
What field was the lecture on: 
Sociology, finance, history
 
Which of the following was TRUE about the candidate?
The candidate allowed questions at any point in the lecture
The candidate discouraged questions during the lecture

Which of the following was TRUE about the candidate?
The candidate seemed condescending at some points during the lecture
The candidate did not seem condescending at any point during the lecture

Which of the following was TRUE about the candidate?
After the lecture, the candidate showed availability to discuss lecture content in person.
After the lecture, the candidate did not show availability to discuss lecture content in person

Control questions
Subject's Gender (Male/Female)
Subject's Age
Subject's years of speaking English
Subject's highest education level
Subject's Country of Birth
Subject's subject matter familiarity (student of finance/social psych or related vs. not)
Ease/difficulty of imagining the lecture/realism of the lecture

q1.value: Using Children and Adolescents as Standardized Patients in Health: A Scoping Review

q3.value: Standardized patients are essential in clinical teaching, training, evaluation, and assessment. In recent years, children and adolescents as standardized patients play an increasingly important role in Pediatrics. Due to the particularity of children and adolescents, the use of children and adolescents as standardized patients has been controversial in the past three decades. This scoping review will expound the current situation, problems, and development of children and adolescents as standardized patients at native and abroad.

q4.value: If children and adolescents as standardized patients is feasible, then it could be use in clinical teaching, training, evaluation, and assessment.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: scoping review

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The following inclusion criteria were used to guide the search and will also be used when reviewing articles: published article; Language: English and Chinese; children and adolescents as standardized patients (age from 0 to 19); standardized parents; database to December 31, 2019
Explicit exclusion criteria identified are: None English and Chinese; none full article; none standardised patients; none children and adolescents standardized patients related population.
Database and other sources: 
online database: MEDLINE via PubMed, EMBASE, Web of Science, CNKI, Wanfang, CBM; Google Scholar and Baidu Xueshu; Reference lists in included studies; Grey literature; ‘similar articles’ in PubMed or other databases; Consult experts and authors
basic information and Subject analysis information
Evidence synthesis

attributes.title: The role of the right dorsolateral prefrontal  cortex in executive functions supporting motor  imagery: A TMS study

q3.value:
The present experiment is designed to provide a test of the Motor-Cognitive Model (MCM) and Functional Equivalence Model (FEM) of motor imagery. In the former, motor imagery is argued to include a large component of executive functions; these are used during motor imagery to elaborate and monitor the motor image. In contrast, overt actions are argued to rely little on executive functions. FEM, in contrast, argues that motor imagery represents the unfolding of a motor program in the absence of physical movement. This theory predicts equivalent roles of including executive functions in both motor imagery and overt action.

Thus, the two theories differ in the predictions they make regarding executive functions. On the one hand, the MCM predicts that interfering with executive functions, behaviourally and/or neurologically, will impair motor imagery to a much greater extent than overt actions. On the other hand, the FEM predicts equal effects of interfering with executive functions on motor imagery and overt actions

Please see attached plan "TMS Effects on Motor Imagery_Pre-registration_SG+MM_28_01_20.pdf"

registration_responses.q3:
The present experiment is designed to provide a test of the Motor-Cognitive Model (MCM) and Functional Equivalence Model (FEM) of motor imagery. In the former, motor imagery is argued to include a large component of executive functions; these are used during motor imagery to elaborate and monitor the motor image. In contrast, overt actions are argued to rely little on executive functions. FEM, in contrast, argues that motor imagery represents the unfolding of a motor program in the absence of physical movement. This theory predicts equivalent roles of including executive functions in both motor imagery and overt action.

Thus, the two theories differ in the predictions they make regarding executive functions. On the one hand, the MCM predicts that interfering with executive functions, behaviourally and/or neurologically, will impair motor imagery to a much greater extent than overt actions. On the other hand, the FEM predicts equal effects of interfering with executive functions on motor imagery and overt actions
